Message.Title: Kara Swisher says Telegraph reporter lied about Facebook/Yahoo search deal
Message.Msg: Yahoo and Facebook are not currently in talks about forming a search alliance, according to my sources, who scoffed about such a deal reported in a thinner-than-tissue-paper post by the Telegraph earlier today. Such a rumor would certainly do wonders for a Yahoo stock pop tomorrow for all the hedge funds now piling into the Silicon Valley Internet giant, would that it were so.

Message.Title: Facebook-Yahoo talks: Who wins?
Message.Msg: If Facebook teams up with Yahoo, who wins and who loses? That's the question today after the Sunday Telegraph in London reported that Yahoo CEO Marissa Mayer is talking to Facebook COO Sheryl Sandberg about uniting the companies' search and social-networking into an online behemoth with more than 1 billion users. That infusion of traffic could give a major boost to YHOO's search, help it recruit top-level developers, and even pose a real competitive threat to Google. FB, meanwhile, has wanted to grow in search to monetize its huge footprint, so the deal could be a win-win for the two companies. The big loser could be Microsoft, which currently has a deal to power YHOO's search with its Bing service. According to the Telegraph, Yahoo hasn't been totally happy with the agreement. Traders have already been sensing that something was up. FB has climbed 24 percent over the last month, and YHOO is up 12 percent in the same period. GOOG and the S&P 500 are both down 7 percent, while MSFT has fallen 10 percent.

Message.Title: Facebook/Yahoo Search Talks Are Real Deal
Message.Msg: According to my sources Facebook and Yahoo are in talks to teamp-up on search. Here's the catch, Microsoft will play a big part in those talks. Microsoft will give up Bing and approximately 400 engineers to Yahoo for shares in Yahoo and Facebook clearing the path for a Yahoo/Facebook search engine.

Topic.Title: Facebook/Yahoo Search Talks Are Real Deal

Message.Msg: From The Wall Street Cheat Sheet: I’d be surprised if Marissa Mayer and Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg weren’t planning a way to combine forces for their mutual benefit. Here’s why: 1. Both CEOs have stated “mobile” is a top near-term objective; 2. Both CEOs are heavily focused on improving user engagement with improved technology; 3. Both companies need each other to take significant marketshare from Google (NASDAQ:GOOG); 4 .Both companies have deals with Microsoft, so that reduces hurdles for certain deals; and, 5. Both companies have different spheres of expertise which could nicely compliment the others’. Lastly, and most importantly, a sexy blockbuster partnership between Facebook and Yahoo will create positive hype for both stocks — something desperately needed given the pain long term shareholders have felt. Although the current search alliance may be pure speculation, don’t rule out an exciting announcement sooner than later.

Message.Title: Facebook Says It Isn’t in Talks to Enter New Search Partnership
Message.Msg: Facebook Inc. (FB), owner of the world’s largest social network, said it isn’t in talks to form a new search partnership and is working on improving its own search capabilities. “People expect a better search experience on Facebook,” the Menlo Park, California-based company said in an e-mailed statement today. “We are working on improvements to better meet those expectations but are not in talks to enter into a new search partnership.” The comments came in response to a story in the Sunday Telegraph that said Facebook was in talks about forging an alliance with Yahoo! Inc. (YHOO), the biggest U.S. Web portal.

Topic.Title: Facebook Says It Isn’t in Talks to Enter New Search Partnership

Message.Msg: A cleverly worded response from Facebook. In other words, they are not dropping Microsoft but they are working on improvements like adding Yahoo! Axis to their search partnership.

Message.Title: Yahoo shares reach 18-month high as investors warm to new CEO
Message.Msg: Yahoo Inc shares reached their highest level in a year and a half, as investor confidence grows that new Chief Executive Marissa Mayer can pull off a comeback that eluded three of her predecessors. Hedge funds Tiger Global Management and Greenlight Capital Management recently disclosed large stakes in Yahoo, accumulated during the third quarter. "Money managers are staring to want to own this name again," said Colin Gillis, an analyst with BGC Partners. Gravity Capital Management's Adam Seessel said that Mayer's recruitment of various Google Inc employees, including recently hired Yahoo Chief Operating Officer Henrique de Castro, has also helped burnish Yahoo's image. "What the market is seeing is not (financial) numbers so much as they're seeing people voting with their feet, people moving from Google to Yahoo," said Seessel, whose firm owns Yahoo shares. "All these people from Google wouldn't be following her if they didn't think that she didn't have some good cards to play," he said. Reuters-
